title: How to Bend Electrical PVC Pipe on the Fly

steps.headline: This is a favorite impromptu installation utilizing the gas barbecue.
steps.description: Most homes have one and they get nice and hot with indirect flames.

steps.headline: Start by firing it up and letting it get warm.
Some models come with a slot on either side that happens to allow the smallest pipe (1/2" to 3/4") to slide right in.
Slip in the PVC pipe and slowly rotate it with the lid closed.
As you rotate and heat the pipe, lift up and down on the end you're holding, while watching the other side of the pipe.
You will notice the pipe start to droop as the conduit becomes warm.
If you are making a full 90-degree bend you can slide the pipe further into the cue to heat a larger section.
steps.description: This helps make the bend without kinking the pipe.

steps.headline: When the pipe is relatively malleable, pull it out and set it down on a flat section of sidewalk.
Make the bend you need (don't go over 90 degrees).
steps.description: It's a good idea to stake the pipe down to hold it in position while it cools.

steps.headline: If you take two bricks, you can sandwich the pipe as needed to complete the necessary bends or offsets.
steps.description: A little shot of cool water from a garden hose will help speed up the cooling of the pipe.

steps.headline: Set up forms - if only one part is necessary, hand bending is fine.
Slide bender into the pipe.
steps.description: It should be sitting in the BendStation, which is an insulating sheath.

steps.headline: Rotate pipe every so often.
steps.description: Smaller diameters will heat faster, so they should be turned more often. This prevents any "grill lines" on the inside of the pipe.

steps.headline: When the pipe is flexible enough for what you are trying to do, pull it off of the bender and shape it into the part you need.
Allow the pipe to cool.
steps.description: You can use a wet sponge or an air gun to speed up the cooling process.

steps.headline: If more than one part is needed, put the next pipe on the bender while the first one cools.
steps.description: Repeat the whole process. By the time your new piece is ready to bend, the first one will be completely cooled.

text: Gas barbecue This is a favorite impromptu installation utilizing the gas barbecue. Most homes have one and they get nice and hot with indirect flames. Start by firing it up and letting it get warm.  Some models come with a slot on either side that happens to allow the smallest pipe (1/2" to 3/4") to slide right in.  Slip in the PVC pipe and slowly rotate it with the lid closed.  As you rotate and heat the pipe, lift up and down on the end you're holding, while watching the other side of the pipe.  You will notice the pipe start to droop as the conduit becomes warm.  If you are making a full 90-degree bend you can slide the pipe further into the cue to heat a larger section. This helps make the bend without kinking the pipe. When the pipe is relatively malleable, pull it out and set it down on a flat section of sidewalk.  Make the bend you need (don't go over 90 degrees). It's a good idea to stake the pipe down to hold it in position while it cools. If you take two bricks, you can sandwich the pipe as needed to complete the necessary bends or offsets. A little shot of cool water from a garden hose will help speed up the cooling of the pipe. PVC Bendit Preheat the bender.  Set up forms - if only one part is necessary, hand bending is fine.  Slide bender into the pipe. It should be sitting in the BendStation, which is an insulating sheath. Rotate pipe every so often. Smaller diameters will heat faster, so they should be turned more often. This prevents any "grill lines" on the inside of the pipe. When the pipe is flexible enough for what you are trying to do, pull it off of the bender and shape it into the part you need.  Allow the pipe to cool. You can use a wet sponge or an air gun to speed up the cooling process. If more than one part is needed, put the next pipe on the bender while the first one cools. Repeat the whole process. By the time your new piece is ready to bend, the first one will be completely cooled.
